block.p: Victor in Mexico Pledges To Clean Up Legal System President-elect Vicente Fox Quesada said he would rebuild the country's federal law enforcement system, moving it toward an American model of justice as a way to wipe out the corruption that has crippled Mexico for decades. He also said he would go to the United States soon to meet with President Clinton and both major presidential candidates to press a proposal to open the border to a less-restricted flow of immigrants.

He also said he would go to the United States soon to meet with President Clinton and both major presidential candidates to press a proposal to open the border to a less-restricted flow of immigrants.
A power struggle has broken out within Mexico's governing party following its election defeat.

Putting Elian Fervor to Use Cuban officials say it will be difficult to sustain the emotional commitment that Cubans have had to the Elian Gonzalez case, now that the boy is home, as the government presses its battle with the United States over the trade embargo and immigration policy.

Missile Threat Questioned Intelligence officials, military officers and policy experts in the Clinton administration are divided over the seriousness of missile threats posed by countries like North Korea, Iran and Iraq, even as the administration says the United States needs to build a missile defense system.

Zimbabwe Economy Suffering Economists predict that the coming months will bring more hardship to Zimbabwe, which is already staggering through its worst economic crisis since 1980. That assessment, in a United Nations report, came as expectations among the poor rose with the opposition's strong showing in parliamentary elections.

Sub-Sahara Africa's Miseries Africans south of the Sahara, an area convulsed in war and weakened by natural disasters, also suffer the broadest range of social and economic disadvantages, a United Nations survey said.

Caution on Palestinian Move Israelis and Palestinians reacted cautiously to a declaration by the Palestinian leadership that a Palestinian state would be declared by mid-September, uncertain whether it was a promise, a threat or another deadline that could be massaged.

Lowered Expectations in Iran With most of their newspapers silenced and many of their activists jailed by conservative courts, reformers have scaled back their agenda for change and are concentrating on regaining a public voice through control of the new Parliament.

Inquiry Into U.S. Eavesdropping A French prosecutor has begun a preliminary inquiry into whether the American global surveillance system, which listens in on millions of phone calls, faxes and e-mail messages each day, is a threat.

Russia Faults Its Commanders Negligence by Russian commanders enabled Chechen suicide bombers to carry out attacks on Sunday that killed more than 30 soldiers, the chief of Russia's intelligence service said. Officials put the final toll at 33 dead, 84 wounded and 3 missing.

Initiative on Gun Shows Heads for Colorado Vote The Colorado Supreme Court has cleared the way for voters to decide in November whether people who buy guns from private sellers at weekend gun shows must undergo the same criminal background checks that buyers from licensed dealers must undergo.

Finding a Way Around Congress Aides to President Clinton say that with the Republican-controlled Congress not inclined to give Democrats comfort in an election year, the administration intends to continue making policy by decree -- putting federal land off limits to developers, reorganizing agencies, tightening pollution rules and pushing other measures that stand little chance of Congressional passage. The aides also do not rule out summer recess appointments of nominees still awaiting Senate confirmation.
Endorsements for Gore The two national teachers' unions, voting at their respective conventions, formally endorsed Vice President Al Gore for president.

New Casualty Category Under legislation signed by President Clinton last month, a plaque will soon be placed near the Vietnam Veterans Memorial in Washington honoring veterans, though not by name, who died after the war from exposure to Agent Orange, post-traumatic stress disorder and other causes not directly related to combat.

Treating Alzheimer's Patients Doctors say people with advanced Alzheimer's disease who are hospitalized for broken hips or pneumonia are often subjected to needless, painful medical procedures and not given enough pain medication.

Benefit, Risk and the Pill A study suggests that while women taking birth control pills are at higher risk of stroke, the risk is outweighed by the contraceptive benefits of the pills. Further, it said, strokes are so rare in women of reproductive age that the increase in risk is of little significance.

Effects of Low Birthweight Research indicates that babies born weighing less than five and a half pounds were almost four times less likely to graduate from high school by age 19 than were siblings who were of normal birthweight.
Charles Snitow The creator of some of the nation's largest trade shows and of trade fairs in New York that helped open Eastern Europe to commerce at the height of the Cold War was 93.

Kemal Sunal One of Turkey's most popular comic actors, he was 55. Mr. Sunal, who had a lifelong fear of flying, died of a heart attack shortly after boarding a commercial flight he had been persuaded to take to a film location.

Tall Ships and Fireworks Herald a Dazzling Fourth More than a million people, including President Clinton, turned out to watch an 11-mile line of tall ships and military vessels from nearly 20 nations parade across New York Harbor and up the Hudson River. The Independence Day celebration was capped by an extravagant nighttime fireworks display along the Manhattan shoreline.

Giuliani Defends Father Mayor Rudolph W. Giuliani defended his father as the ''finest man'' he has ever known, as reporters questioned him at a news conference about a report that the elder Giuliani had spent time in prison after being convicted of armed robbery decades ago.

So Much for Vacation More students than ever before are enrolled in school this summer, with the 53 largest urban districts having about one in five students in class this month; more than 40 percent of students are in school in Chicago, Miami and St. Louis.
New York City opens its schools today for a vast summer session serving more than one in four pupils, part of a reshaping of public education that presses students to meet ever-higher standards.

Teachers Salaries Rise, a Little A teachers' union report said beginning and average teacher salaries rose more than 3 percent last year, but were still short of earnings by other college-educated workers and, adjusted for inflation, remained below teacher salaries from 1972.

Sister to Face Sister Venus Williams beat Martina Hingis, 6-3, 4-6, 6-4, to advance to the Wimbledon semifinals tomorrow, where her opponent will be her sister, Serena Williams, who defeated Lisa Raymond, 6-2, 6-0.

Catchers Lead All-Stars Mike Piazza of the Mets got 2,780,452 votes, the most of any player in the National League, while catcher Ivan Rodriguez of the Texas Rangers led all major leaguers with 2,808,456.
A Frenchman Leads the Tour Laurent Jalabert took the lead in the Tour de France, with Lance Armstrong, the defending champion, slipping to third, 24 seconds back.

Home Heating Costs May Rise The rising cost of heating oil and natural gas threaten to make it significantly more expensive to heat American homes this winter, even with a new pledge by Saudi Arabia to increase production to help reduce global petroleum prices.

Japan Rate Increase Possible The Bank of Japan, faced with a growing body of evidence that the Japanese economy is gaining momentum, could decide later this month to raise interest rates from their near-zero level. Such a move would be the first increase in Japanese rates in a decade.

Stocks Abroad Are Mixed Stocks in Mexico continued to rally as investors showed enthusiasm for the election of the opposition presidential candidate, Vicente Fox Quesada. In Europe, stock markets were generally weaker. In Japan, the Nikkei shed 144.51 points, to 17,470.15. But in Hong Kong, share prices closed higher.

Glass Work to Open Festival The Brooklyn Academy of Music will open its 2000 Next Wave Festival on Oct. 4 with Philip Glass's Symphony No. 5, a 12-movement work that explores spiritual traditions through the ages.
